scenes.location: OLD MOORISH SECTION OF THE CITY
characters: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF THE GERMAN OCCUPATION OF FR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first only the turrets and rooftops are visible agains a torrid sky. The facades of the Moorish buildings give way to a narrow twisting street crowded with the polyglot life of a nativ quarter. The intense desert sun holds the scene in a torp tranquility. Activity is unhurried and sounds are muted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER takes a piece of paper from the typewrit turns to a microphone, and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To all officers! Two German couriers carrying important official documents murdered on train from Oran. Murderer and possible accomplices headed for Casablanca. Round up all suspicious characters and search them for stolen documents. Important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An officer BLOWS his whistle several times. There is pandemonium as native guards begin to round up people. A police car, full of officers, with SIREN BLARING, screa through the street and stops in the market. Some try to escape but are caught by the police and loade into a police wagon. At a street corner TWO POLICEMEN stop a white CIVILIAN an question him.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: May we see your papers?

dialogues.speaker: CIVILIAN
dialogues.text: (nervously) I don't think I have them on me.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: In that case, we'll have to ask you to come along. The civilian pats his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: CIVILIAN
dialogues.text: Wait. It's just possible that I... Yes, here they are. He brings out his papers. The second policeman examines them.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: These papers expired three weeks ago. You'll have to come along. Suddenly the civilian breaks away and starts to run wildl  down the street. The policeman SHOUTS "Halt", but the civilian keeps going JAN and ANNINA BRANDEL, a very young and attractive refug couple from Bulgaria, watch as the civilian passes. They' been thrust by circumstances from a simple country life i an unfamiliar and hectic world. A shot RINGS out, and the man falls to the ground. Above him, painted on the wall, is a large poster of Marshal Petain, which reads: "Je tiens mes promesses, meme celles des autres." The policeman frantically searches the body, but only finds Free French literature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an inscription carved in a marble block along the roofline of the building: "Liberte, Egalite, Fraternite" We see the the facade, French in architecture, then the h vaulted entrance which is inscribed "Palais de Justice". At the entrance the arrested suspects are led in by the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged ENGLISH COUPLE sit at a table just off the square, and observe the commotion across the way in front the Palais de Justice. The police van pulls up. The rear doors are opened and people stream out. A EUROPEAN man, sitting at a table nearby, watches the English couple more closely than the scene on the street.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
dialogues.text: What on earth's going on there?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know, my dear. The European walks over to the couple.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Pardon, pardon, Monsieur, pardon  Madame, have you not heard?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: We hear very little, and we understand even less.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Two German couriers were found murdered in the desert... the unoccupied desert. This is the customary roundup of refugees, liberals, and uh, of course, a beautiful young girl for Monsieur Renault, the Prefect of Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suspects are herded out of the van, and into the Palais de Justice.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, along with these unhappy refugees the scum of Europe has gravitated to Casablanca. Some of them have been waiting years for a visa. He puts his left arm compassionately around the Englishma and reaches behind the man with his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: I beg of you, Monsieur, watch yourself. Be on guard. This place is full of vultures, vultures everywhere, everywhere. The Englishman seems to be taken aback by this sudden dis of concern.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: Ha, ha, thank you, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Not at all. Au revoir, Monsieur. Au revoir, Madame. He leaves. The Englishman, still a trifle disconcerted by  the European's action, watches him as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: Au revoir. Amusing little fellow. Waiter! As he pats both his breast and pants pockets he realizes there is something missing.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. How silly of me.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
dialogues.text: What, dear?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: I've left my wallet in the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISHWOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Suddenly the Englishman looks off in the direction of the departed European, the clouds of suspicion gathering. Interrupting overhead is the DRONE of a low flying airpla They look up.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: An airplane cuts its motor for landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refugees wait in line outside the Palais de Justice. Thei upturned gaze follows the flight of the plane. In their faces is revealed one hope they all have in common, and t plane is the symbol of that hope. Jan and Annina look up at the plane.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Perhaps tomorrow we'll be on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The plane SWOOPS down past a sign atop a building at the edge of the airport. The sign reads "Rick's Cafe Americain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plane lands a swastika on its tail is clearly visible. It taxis to a stop as a group of officers march into formation in front of it. Behind them stand a detail of native soldiers keeping guard. In the group is CAPTAIN LOUIS RENAULT, a French officer appointed by Vichy as Prefect of Police in Casablanca. He is a handsome, middle-aged Frenchman, debonair and gay, b withal a shrewd and alert official. With him are HERR HEINZE, the German consul, CAPTAIN TONE an Italian officer, and LIEUTENANT CASSELLE, Renault's ai When the plane door opens, the first passenger to step ou is a tall, middle-aged, pale German with a smile that see more the result of a frozen face muscle than a cheerful disposition. On any occasion when MAJOR STRASSER is cross his expression hardens into iron. Herr Heinze steps up to him with upraised arm.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: It is very good to see you again, Major Strasser.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. Heinze introduces Strasser to Renault.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: May I present Captain Renault, Police Prefect of Casablanca. Major Strasser. Renault salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unoccupied France welcomes you to Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (in perfect English, smiling) Thank you, Captain. It's very good to be here.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Major Strasser, my aide, Lieutenant Casselle. As they acknowledge each other, Captain Tonelli barges in front of Casselle and salutes Strasser.

dialogues.speaker: TONELLI
dialogues.text: Captain Tonelli, the Italian service, at your command, Major.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: That is kind of you. But Tonelli gets no further than that as Strasser turns again to Renault. They walk away from the plane, Heinze following, with Casselle and Tonelli bringing up the rear engaged in a heated exchange of words.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You may find the climate of Casablanca a trifle warm, Major.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Oh, we Germans must get used to all climates, from Russia to the Sahara. But perhaps you were not referring to the weather.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (sidesteps the implication with a smile) What else, my dear Major?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (casually) By the way, the murder of the couriers, what has been done?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Realizing the importance of the case, my men are rounding up twice the usual number of suspects.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: We already know who the murderer is.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Good. Is he in custody?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, there is no hurry. Tonight he'll be at Rick's. Everybody comes to Rick's.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I have already heard about this cafe, and also about Mr. Rick himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neon sign above the door is brightly lit. Customers arrive and go in through the front door. From inside we hear sounds of MUSIC and LAUGHTER. The song is "It Had to Be You." Again we isolate on the neon sign. INSERT SIGN: "Rick's Cafe Americain". We follow a group of customers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick's is an expensive and chic nightclub which definitel possesses an air of sophistication and intrigue. SAM, a middle-aged Negro, sits on a stool before a small, salmon-colored piano on wheels, playing and singing while accompanied by a small orchestra. All about him there is the HUM of voices, CHATTER and LAUGHTER. The occupants of the room are varied. There are Europeans in their dinner jackets, their women beautifully begowned and bejeweled. There are Moroccans in silk robes. Turks wearing fezzes. Levantines. Naval officers. Members of the Foreign Legion, distinguished by their kepis. Two men sit at a table.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Waiting, waiting, waiting. I'll never get out of here. I'll die in  Casablanca. His companion seems uninterested in his dilemma. Sympathy is evidently in short supply in Casablanca. At another table a very well-dressed WOMAN talks toa MOOR. She has a bracelet on her wrist. No other jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: But can't you make it just a little more? Please.

dialogues.speaker: MOOR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Madame, but diamonds are a drug on the market. Everybody sells diamonds. There are diamonds everywhere. Two thousand, four hundred.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: All right. On to another table where two CONSPIRATORS talk.

dialogues.speaker: CONSPIRATOR
dialogues.text: The trucks are waiting, the men are waiting. Everything is... He stops abruptly as two German officers walk by. A REFUGEE and another MAN converse at another table.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It's the fishing smack Santiago. It leaves at one tomorrow night, here from the end of La Medina. Third boat.

dialogues.speaker: REFUGEE
dialogues.text: Thank you, oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And bring fifteen thousand francs in cash. Remember, in cash. On the way to the bar we pass several tables and hear a Babel of foreign tongues. Here and there we catch a scattered phrase or sentence in English. SACHA, a friendly young Russian bartender, hands a drink a customer with the Russian equivalent of "Bottoms Up." T customer answers with "Cheerio." CARL, the waiter, is a fat, jovial German refugee with  10. spectacles. He walks, tray in hand, to a private door, over which ABDUL, a large, burly man, stands guard.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Open up, Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: (respectfully) Yes, Herr Professor. Abdul opens the door and Carl goes into the gambling room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their is much activity at the various tables. At one tabl TwO WOMEN and a MAN play cards. They glance at another ta One of them calls to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
dialogues.text: Uh, waiter.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, Madame?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
dialogues.text: Will you ask Rick if he'll have a drink with us?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Madame, he never drinks with customers. Never. I have never seen him.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
dialogues.text: (disappointedly) What makes saloon-keepers so snobbish?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (to Carl) Perhaps if you told him I ran the second largest banking house in Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: The second largest? That wouldn't impress Rick. The leading banker in Amsterdam is now the pastry chef in our kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: We have something to look forward to.  11.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And his father is the bell boy. Carl laughs. The overseer walks up to a table with a paper in his hand Then we see a drink and a man's hand, but nothing more. T overseer places a check on the table. The hand picks up t check and writes on it, in pencil, "Okay-Rick." The overseer takes the check. We now see RICK, sitting at a table alone playing solitar chess. Rick is an American of indeterminate age. There is no expression on his face -- complete deadpan. There is a commotion at the door as people attempt to com into the gambling room. He nods approval to Abdul. Then a GERMAN appears in the doorway. Abdul looks to Rick who glances back toward the open door and nods "no". Abdul starts to close the door on the man.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir, this is a private room.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: Of all the nerve! who do you think... I know there's gambling in there! There's no secret. You dare not keep me out of here! The man tries to push his way through the door as Rick walks up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (coldly) Yes? What's the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: This gentleman -- The German interrupts and waves his card.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: I've been in every gambling room between Honolulu and Berlin and if you think I'm going to be kept out of a saloon like this, you're very much mistaken. At this moment UGARTE, a small, thin man with a nervous a  12. tries to squeeze through the doorway blocked by the Germa If he were an American, Ugarte would look like a tout. He gets through and passes Rick.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Uh, excuse me, please. Hello, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (softly) Hello Ugarte. Rick looks at the German calmly, takes the card out of hi hand, and tears it up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Your cash is good at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: What! Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I do. You're lucky the bar's open to you.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: This is outrageous. I shall report it to the Angriff! The German storms off, tossing the pieces of his card int the air behind him. Rick meets Ugarte on his way back to his table.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: (fawning) Huh. You know, Rick, watching you just now with the Deutsches Bank one would think you'd been doing this all your life.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (stiffening) Well, what makes you think I haven't?

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Oh, nothing. But when you first came to Casablanca, I thought --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (coldly)  13. -- You thought what? Fearing to offend Rick, Ugarte laughs.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: What right do I have to think? Ugarte pulls out a chair at Rick's table.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: May I? Too bad about those two German couriers, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (indifferently) They got a lucky break. Yesterday they were just two German clerks. Today they're the 'Honored Dead'.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: You are a very cynical person, Rick, if you'll forgive me for saying so. Ugarte sits down.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (shortly) I forgive you. A waiter comes up to the table with a tray of drinks. He places one before Ugarte.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Rick) Will you have a drink with me please?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: I forgot. You never drink with... (to waiter) I'll have another, please. (to Rick, sadly) You despise me, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (indifferently) If I gave you any thought, I probably would.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: But why? Oh, you object to the kind  He takes 14. of business I do, huh? But think of all those poor refugees who must rot in this place if I didn't help them. That's not so bad. Through ways of my own I provide them with exit visas.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: For a price, Ugarte, for a price.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: But think of all the poor devils who cannot meet Renault's price. I get it for them for half. Is that so parasitic?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I don't mind a parasite. I object to a cut-rate one.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Well, Rick, after tonight I'll be through with the whole business, and I am leaving finally this Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Who did you bribe for your visa? Renault or yourself?

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: (ironically) Myself. I found myself much more reasonable. an envelope from his pocket and lays it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Look, Rick, do you know what this is? Something that even you have never seen. Letters of transit signed by General de Gaulle. Cannot be rescinded, not even questioned. Rick appears ready to take them form Ugarte.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: One moment. Tonight I'll be selling those for more money than even I have ever dreamed of, and then, addio Casablanca! You know, Rick, I have many friends in Casablanca, but somehow, just because you despise me you're the only one I trust. Will you keep these for me? Please.  15.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Perhaps an hour, perhaps a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I don't want them here overnight.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid of that. Please keep them for me. Thank you. I knew I could trust you. Rick takes them. Ugarte leaves the table just as the wait comes up.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Oh, waiter. I'll be expecting some people. If anybody asks for me, I'll be right here.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur. The waiter leaves. Ugarte turns to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Rick, I hope you are more impressed with me now, huh? If you'll forgive me, I'll share my good luck with your roulette wheel. He starts across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just a moment. Ugarte stops as Rick comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard a rumor that those German couriers were carrying letters of transit. Ugarte hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Huh? I heard that rumor, too. Poor devils. Rick looks at Ugarte steadily.  16.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (slowly) Yes, you're right, Ugarte. I ama little more impressed with you. Rick leaves the gambling room and goes into the main room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick makes his way over to Sam, who plays and sings the "Knock Wood" number, accompanied by the orchestra. The cafe is in semi-darkness. The spotlight is on Sam, and every time the orchestra comes in on the "Knock Wood" business, the spotlight swings over to the orchestra. During one of the periods when the spotlight is on the orchestra, Rick slips the letters of transit into the pia FERRARI, owner of the Blue Parrot, a competing night spot, comes into the cafe, sits down, and watches Sam. Then he sees Rick and they smile at each other. At the end of the number Ferrari goes to the bar to speak to Ric

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Hello, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Hello, Ferrari. How's business at the Blue Parrot?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Fine, but I would like to buy your cafe.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It's not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: You haven't heard my offer.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It's not for sale at any price.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: What do you want for Sam?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I don't buy or sell human beings.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Rick and 17. That's too bad. That's Casablanca's leading commodity. In refugees alone we could make a fortune if you would work with me through the black market.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Suppose you run your business and let me run mine.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Suppose we ask Sam. Maybe he'd like to make a change.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Suppose we do.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: My dear Rick, when will you realize that in this world today isolationism is no longer a practical policy? Ferrari walk over to the piano.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sam, Ferrari wants you to work for him at the Blue Parrot.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I like it fine here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He'll double what I pay you.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I ain't got time to spend the money I make here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sorry. Apparently satisfied, Ferrari walks away. Back at the bar, YVONNE, an attractive young French woman sits on a stool drinking brandy. Sacha, who looks at her with lovesick eyes, fills her tumbler.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: The boss's private stock. Because, Yvonne, I loff you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morosely) Oh, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: (fondly) All right, all right. For you, Yvonne, I shot opp, because, Yvonne, I loff you. Uh oh. Rick saunters over and leans on the bar, next to Yvonne. He pays no attention to her. She looks at him bitterly, without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Oh, Monsieur Rick, Monsieur Rick. Some Germans, boom, boom, boom, boom, gave this check. Is it all right? Rick looks the check over and tears it up. Yvonne has never taken her eyes off Rick.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That's so long ago, I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Will I see you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (matter -of-factly) I never make plans that far ahead. Yvonne turns, looks at Sacha, and extends her glass to hi

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Give me another.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sacha, she's had enough.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him, Sacha. Fill it up.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yvonne, I loff you, but he pays me. Yvonne wheels on Rick with drunken fury.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Rick, I'm sick and tired of having  19. you --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Sacha, call a cab.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yes, boss. Rick takes Yvonne by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Come on, we're going to get your coat.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Take your hands off me! He pulls her along toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No. You're going home. You've had a little too much to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacha stands at the curb on the street in front of Rick's and signals for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Taxi! Soon one pulls up. Rick and Yvonne come out of the cafe. He puts a coat over her shoulders and she objects violently.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are, pushing me around? What a fool I was to fall for a man like you. Rick and Yvonne approach the waiting cab.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Sacha) You'd better go with her, Sacha, to be sure she gets home.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yes, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And come right back.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: (his face falling) Yes, boss. Rick stands and looks up at the revolving beacon light fr the airport. It intermittently sheds its light on Rick's face. Renault sits at a table on the cafe terrace, watching thi evening's performance.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Hello, Rick. Rick walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Hello, Louis.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: How extravagant you are, throwing away women like that. Someday they may be scarce. Rick sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (amused) You know, I think now I shall pay a call on Yvonne, maybe get her on the rebound, eh?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: When it comes to women, you're a true democrat. As they talk, Captain Tonelli and Lieutenant Casselle wal toward the entrance of the cafe. Casselle talks non-stop Tonelli tries. They both stop, salute Renault, and walk i the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: If he gets a word in it'll bea major Italian victory. Rick laughs. Rick and Renault look up when they hear the BUZZ of a pla taking off from the adjacent airfield. The plane flies di over their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane to Lisbon. (pause) You would like to be on it?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (curtly) Why? What's in Lisbon?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: The clipper to America. Rick doesn't answer. His look isn't a happy one.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I have often speculated on why you don't return to America. Did you abscond with the church funds? Did you run off with a senator's wife? I like to think you killed a man. It's the romantic in me. Rick still looks in the direction of the airport.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It was a combination of all three.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: And what in heaven's name brought you to Casablanca?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: My health. I came to Casablanca for the waters.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Waters? What waters? We're in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I was misinformed.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Huh! EMIL, the croupier, comes out of the cafe and walks over to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: EMIL
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Monsieur Rick, but a gentleman inside has won twenty thousand francs. The cashier would like some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll get it from the safe.

dialogues.speaker: EMIL
dialogues.text: I am so upset, Monsieur Rick. You know I can't understand --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Forget it, Emil. Mistakes like that happen all the time.

dialogues.speaker: EMIL
dialogues.text: I'm awfully sorry. The three men enter the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass Sam at the piano. He's playing "Baby Face". Ric pats Sam on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Rick, there's going to be some excitement here tonight. We are going to make an arrest in your cafe.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (somewhat annoyed) What, again?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: This is no ordinary arrest. A murderer, no less. Rick's eyes react. Involuntarily, they glance toward the gambling room. Renault catches the look.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: If you are thinking of warning him, don't put yourself out. He cannot possibly escape.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I stick my neck out for nobody.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: A wise foreign policy. They start upstairs to Rick's office, passing Casselle wh is still haranguing Tonelli.  23.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You know, Rick, we could have made this arrest earlier in the evening at the Blue Parrot, but out of my high regard for you we are staging it here. It will amuse your customers.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Our entertainment is enough. They go inside the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick opens up the safe in a small, dark room just off the office. out. Only Rick's shadow can be seen getting the money

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Rick, we are to have an important guest tonight, Major Strasser of the Third Reich, no less. We want him to be here when we make the arrest. A little demonstration of the efficiency of my administration. Rick moves out of the shadows and into view. He gives

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I see. And what's Strasser doing here? He certainly didn't come all the way to Casablanca to witness a demonstration of your efficiency.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Perhaps not. the money to Emil.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: EMIL
dialogues.text: It shall not happen again, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That's all right. Emil departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, you've got something on your mind. Why don't you spill it? Rick closes the door to the office, then goes over to clo the safe.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: How observant you are. As a matter of fact, I wanted to give you a word of advice.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Have a brandy?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Thank you. Rick, there are many exit visas sold in this cafe, but we know that you have never sold one. That is the reason we permit you to remain open.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I thought it was because we let you win at roulette.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: That is another reason. There is a man who's arrived in Casablanca on his way to America. He will offer a fortune to anyone who will furnish him with an exit visa.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah? What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo? Renault watches Rick's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Rick, that is the first time I have ever seen you so impressed.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, he's succeeded in impressing half the world.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: It is my duty to see that he doesn't impress the other half. Rick, Laszlo  They sit 25. must never reach America. He stays in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It'll be interesting to see how he Manages.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Manages what?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: His escape.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, but I just told you. --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Stop it. He escaped froma concentration camp and the Nazis have been chasing him all over Europe.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: This is the end of the chase.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand francs says it isn't. down to discuss the matter in earnest.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Is that a serious offer?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I just paid out twenty. I'd like to get it back.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Make it ten. I am only a poor corrupt official.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Done. No matter how clever he is, he still needs an exit visa, or I should say, two.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why two?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: He is traveling with a lady.  26.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He'll take one.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I think not. I have seen the lady. And if he did not leave her in Marseilles, or in Oran, he certainly won't leave her in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe he's not quite as romantic as you are.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. There is no exit visa for him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Louis, whatever gave you the impression that I might be interested in helping Laszlo escape?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Because, my dear Ricky, I suspect that under that cynical shell you're at heart a sentimentalist. Rick makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, laugh if you will, but I happen to be familiar with your record. Let me point out just two items. In 1935 you ran guns to Ethiopia. In 1936, you fought in Spain on the Loyalist side.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And got well paid for it on both occasions.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: The winning side would have paid you much better.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe. Well, it seems you are determined to keep Laszlo here.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I have my orders.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Gestapo spank. Renault stands up.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: My dear Ricky, you overestimate the influence of the Gestapo. I don't interfere with them and they don't interfere with me. In Casablanca I am master of my fate. I am captain of my -- He stops short as his AIDE enters.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: -- Major Strasser is here, sir. Renault starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, you were saying?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (hurriedly) Excuse me. He hurries away. Rick smiles cynically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renault walks up to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Carl, see that Major Strasser gets a good table, one close to the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I have already given him the best, knowing he is German and would take it anyway. Renault walks over to one of his officers.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Take him quietly. Two guards at every door.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Everything is ready, sir. The officer salutes and goes off to speak to the guards.  28. Renault walks over to Strasser's table as Rick comes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Good evening, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Good evening, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: Won't you join us? Renault sits down.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Thank you. It is a pleasure to have you here, Major.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Champagne and a tin of caviar.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: May I recommend Veuve Cliquot '26, a good French wine.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Very well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: A very interesting club.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Especially so tonight, Major. Ina few minutes you will see the arrest of the man who murdered your couriers.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I expected no less, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugarte stands at the roulette table. Two gendarmes approa him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: GENDARME
dialogues.text: Monsieur Ugarte? Ugarte looks around.  29.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: GENDARME
dialogues.text: Will you please come with us.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Certainly. May I first please cash my chips? The officer nods. They follow Ugarte to the cashier's window. Ugarte puts his chips through the window to the CASHIER.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Pretty lucky, huh? Two thousand, please. Two more guards station themselves at the door in case th is trouble.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Ugarte starts to walk out, followed by the gendarmes. Whe he reaches the doorway he suddenly rushes through and sla the door behind himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time the gendarmes manage to get the door open aga Ugarte has pulled a gun. He FIRES at the doorway. The SHOTS bring on pandemonium i the cafe. As Ugarte runs through the hallway he sees Rick, appearin from the opposite direction, and grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Rick! Rick, help me!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool. You can't get away.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Rick, hide me. Do something! You must help me, Rick. Do something!  30. Guards and gendarmes rush in and grab Ugarte. Rick stands impassively as they drag Ugarte off.

dialogues.speaker: UGARTE
dialogues.text: Rick! Rick! We move to Strasser's table, who has witnessed the event.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Excellent, Captain. Back to Rick, still standing where he was, as a CUSTOMER walks by.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: When they come to get me, Rick, I hope you'll be more of a help.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I stick my neck out for nobody. Rick comes out to the middle of the floor. An air of tens expectancy pervades the room. A few customers are on the point of leaving. Rick speaks in a very calm voice.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry there was a disturbance, folks, but it's all over now. Everything's all right. Just sit down and have a good time. Enjoy yourself. Rick glances toward Sam.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All right, Sam. Sam nods and begins to play. Renault, Strasser, and Heinze sit calmly at their table after witnessing the arrest. Rick walks by.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (calling to Rick) Oh, Rick? Rick stops and comes over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Rick, this is Major Heinrich Strasser of the Third Reich.  31.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, how do you do?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: And you already know Herr Heinze of the Third Reich. Rick nods to Strasser and Heinze.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Please join us, Mr. Rick. Rick sits down with them.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: We are very honored tonight, Rick. Major Strasser is one of the reasons the Third Reich enjoys the reputation it has today.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You repeat "Third Reich" as though you expected there to be others.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well, personally, Major, I will take what comes.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (to Rick) Do you mind if I ask you a few questions? Unofficially, of course.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Make it official, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: What is your nationality?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (pokerfaced) I'm a drunkard.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: That makes Rick a citizen of the world.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I was born in New York City if that'll help you any.  32.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I understand you came here from Paris at the time of the occupation.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: There seems to be no secret about that.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Are you one of those people who cannot imagine the Germans in their beloved Paris?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It's not particularly my beloved Paris.

dialogues.speaker: HEINZE
dialogues.text: Can you imagine us in London?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: When you get there, ask me.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Ho, diplomatist!

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: How about New York?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, there are certain sections of New York, Major, that I wouldn't advise you to try to invade.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Aha. Who do you think will win the war?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I haven't the slightest idea.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Rick is completely neutral about everything. And that takes in the field of women, too.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You weren't always so carefully neutral. We have a complete dossier on you. Strasser takes a little black book from his pocket and tu to a certain page.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Strasser 33. "Richard Blaine, American. Age, thirty-seven. Cannot return to his country." looks up from the book

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: The reason is a little vague. We also know what you did in Paris, Mr. Blaine, and also we know why you left Paris. Rick reaches over and takes the book from Strasser's hand

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Don't worry. We are not going to broadcast it. Rick looks up from the book.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Are my eyes really brown?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You will forgive my curiosity, Mr. Blaine. The point is, an enemy of the Reich has come to Casablanca and we are checking up on anybody who can be of any help to us.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (glances toward Renault) My interest in whether Victor Laszlo stays or goes is purely a sporting one.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: In this case, you have no sympathy for the fox, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Not particularly. I understand the point of view of the hound, too.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo published the foulest lies in the Prague newspapers until the very day we marched in, and even after that he continued to print scandal sheets in a cellar.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Of course, one must admit he has great courage.  34.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I admit he is very clever. Three times he slipped through our fingers. In Paris he continued his activities. We intend not to let it happen again. Rick gets up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You'll excuse me, gentlemen. Your business is politics. Mine is running a saloon.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Blaine. Rick walks away toward the gambling room.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You see, Major, you have nothing to worry about Rick.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Perhaps. A couple comes in the front door. They are VICTOR LASZLO, the Czech resistance leader, and a very pretty young woma wearing a simple white gown, MISS ILSA LUND. She is so beautiful, in fact, that people turn to stare. The HEADWAITER comes up to them.

dialogues.speaker: HEADWAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I reserved a table. Victor Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: HEADWAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur Laszlo. Right this way. As the headwaiter takes them to a table they pass by the piano, and the woman looks at Sam. Sam, with a conscious effort, keeps his eyes on the keybo as they go past. He appears to know this woman. After she has gone by Sam steals a look in her direction. BERGER, a Slight, middle-aged man, observes the couple fr a distance. The headwaiter seats Ilsa. Laszlo takes the chair opposit and surveys the room.  Strasser and Renault look up at them from their table.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Two cointreaux, please.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (to Ilsa) I saw no one of Ugarte's description.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Victor, I, I feel somehow we shouldn't stay here.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: If we would walk out so soon, it would only call attention to us. Perhaps Ugarte's in some other part of the cafe. Berger walks up to their table.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but you look like a couple who are on their way to America.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Well? Berger takes a ring from his finger.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: You will find a market there for this ring. I am forced to sell it at a great sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I hardly think --

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: -- Then perhaps for the lady. The ring is quite unique. He holds it down for their view. Carefully lifting up the stone, he reveals... INSERT - a gold plate in the setting underneath, an impression of the Lorraine Cross of General de Gaulle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I'm very interested. Berger sits down with them.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (lower voice) What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Berger, Norwegian, and at your service, sir. Renault approaches the table from behind Laszlo. Ilsa tri to warn him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Victor... Laszlo understands.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I'll meet you in a few minutes at the bar. (in a louder voice) I do not think we want to buy the ring. But thank you for showing it to us. Berger, taking the cue, sighs and puts the ring away.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Such a bargain. But that is your decision?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It is. Berger gets up and leaves as Renault moves to the table.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Monsieur Laszlo, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I am Captain Renault, Prefect of Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What is it you want?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (amiably) Merely to welcome you to Casablanca and wish you a pleasant stay. It is not often we have so distinguished a visitor.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you. I hope you'll forgive me, Captain, but the present French administration has not always been so cordial. May I present Miss Ilsa Lund?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I was informed you were the most beautiful woman ever to visit Casablanca. That was a gross understatement. Ilsa's manner is friendly and reserved, her voice low and soft.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You are very kind.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Won't you join us? He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: If you will permit me. (calls to the waiter) Oh, Emil. Please, a bottle of your best champagne, and put it on my bill.

dialogues.speaker: EMIL
dialogues.text: Very well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: No, Captain, please.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: No. Please, Monsieur, it is a little game we play. They put it on the bill, I tear the bill up. It is very convenient. Ilsa glances off in Sam's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, the boy who is playing the piano, somewhere I have seen him.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: He came from Paris with Rick.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Rick? Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (smiling) Mademoiselle, you are in Rick's and Rick is --

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: -- Is what?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well, Mademoiselle, he's the kind of aman that, well, if I were a woman and I... (taps his chest) were not around, I should be in love with Rick. But what a fool I am talking to a beautiful woman about another man. Renault jumps to his feet as Strasser enters.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Ah, Major. Mademoiselle Lund, Monsieur Laszlo, may I present Major Heinrich Strasser. Strasser bows and smiles pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: How do you do. This is a pleasure I have long looked forward to. There is not the slightest recognition from either Ilsa or Laszlo. Strasser waits to be asked to seat himself.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll excuse me if I am  39. not gracious, but you see, Major Strasser, I'm a Czechoslovakian.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You were a Czechoslovakian. Now you are a subject of the German Reich! Laszlo stands.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I've never accepted that privilege, and I'm now on French soil.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I should like to discuss some matters arising from your presence on French soil.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: This is hardly the time or the place.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (hardening) Then we shall state another time and another place. Tomorrow at ten in the Prefect's office, with Mademoiselle.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Captain Renault, I am under your authority. Is it your order that we come to your office?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (amiably) Let us say that it is my request. That is a much more pleasant word.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Very well. Renault and Strasser bow shortly.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle. Renault and Strasser walk away.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: A very clever tactical retreat,  40. Major. Strasser looks at Renault sharply, but sees only a noncommittal smile on Renault's face. Laszlo remains standing at the table as Strasser and Renault leave.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: This time they really mean to stop me.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Victor, I'm afraid for you.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We have been in difficult places before, haven't we? Ilsa smiles back at him, but her eyes are still troubled. On the floor, CORINA strums a guitar and begins her numbe Meanwhile, Laszlo looks about with apparent casualness. H sees Strasser and Renault whispering together, then notic Berger at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I must find out what Berger knows.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I will, don't worry. He rises and goes off. We see Ilsa's troubled profile. While Corina sings, Sam gives a worried glance in Ilsa's direction. Ilsa watches him. At the bar, Berger sips a drink. Laszlo walks up and casually takes a place at the bar next to Berger.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Mr. Berger, the ring, could I see it again?

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sacha) A champagne cocktail, please. Laszlo takes the ring and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I recognize you from the news photographs, Monsieur Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: In a concentration camp, one is apt to lose a little weight.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: We read five times that you were killed in five different places.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (smiles wryly) AS you see, it was true every single time. Thank heaven I found you, Berger. I am looking for a man by the name of Ugarte. He is supposed to help me. Berger shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Ugarte cannot even help himself, Monsieur. He is under arrest for murder. He was arrested here tonight. Laszlo absorbs the shock quietly.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: (with intense devotion) But we who are still free will do all we can. We are organized, Monsieur, underground like everywhere else. Tomorrow night there is a meeting at the Caverne du Bois. If you would come... He stops when Sacha brings the drink to Laszlo. Corina finishes her song, and the crowd applauds quite enthusiastically. Ilsa sits alone at her table.  42.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (to waiter) Will you ask the piano player to come over here, please?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Very well, Mademoiselle. Renault comes up to the bar near Berger and Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: How's the jewelry business, Berger?

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Er, not so good. (to Sacha) May I have my check, please?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Too bad you weren't here earlier, Monsieur Laszlo. We had quite a bit of excitement this evening, didn't we, Berger?

dialogues.speaker: BERGER
dialogues.text: Er, yes. Excuse me, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: My bill.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: No. Two champagne cocktails, please.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Sam wheels in the piano to Ilsa's table. On his face is that funny fear. Ilsa herself is not as self-possessed as she tries to appear. There is something behind this, some mystery.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Hello, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Ilsa. I never expected to see you again. He sits down and is ready to play.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It's been a long time.  43.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. A lot of water under the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Some of the old songs, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Sam begins to play a number. He is nervous, waiting for anything.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Where is Rick?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (evading) I don't know. I ain't seen him all night. Sam looks very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: When will he be back?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Not tonight no more. He ain't coming. Uh, he went home.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Does he always leave so early?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, he never... well... (desperately) he's got a girl up at the Blue Parrot. He goes up there all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You used to be a much better liar, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, Miss Ilsa. You're bad luck to him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Play it once, Sam, for old time's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean, Miss Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Play it, Sam. Play "As Time Goes By."

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh I can't remember it, Miss Ilsa. I'm a little rusty on it. Of course he can. He doesn't want to play it. He seems even more scared now.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I'll hum it for you. Ilsa starts to hum. Sam begins to play it very softly.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Sing it, Sam. And Sam sings.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You must remember this, A kiss is just a kiss, A sigh is just a sigh, The fundamental things apply, As time goes by. The door to the gambling room opens. Rick comes swinging out. He's heard the music and he's livid.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: And when two lovers woo, They both say I love you, On that you can rely, No matter what the future brings, As time goes by. Rick walks briskly up to the piano.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sam, I thought I told you never to play... As he sees Ilsa he stops short. Sam stops playing. Two close-ups reveal Ilsa and Rick seeing each other. Rick appears shocked. For a long moment he just looks at Sam prepares to move the piano away.  45. Renault and Laszlo approach the table from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (to Ilsa) Well, you were asking about Rick and here he is. Mademoiselle, may I present --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Hello, Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Hello, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, you've already met Rick, Mademoiselle? There's no answer from either.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well then, perhaps you also ---

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: -- This is Mr. Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: One hears a great deal about Rick in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And about Victor Laszlo everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Won't you join us for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, no, Rick never --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Thanks. I will. Rick sits down.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well! A precedent is being broken.  46. Er, Emil!

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: This is a very interesting cafe. I congratulate you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And I congratulate you.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Your work.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you. I try.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: We all try. You succeed.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I can't get over you two. She was asking about you earlier, Rick, ina way that made me extremely jealous.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (to Rick) I wasn't sure you were the same. Let's see, the last time we met --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- It was "La Belle Aurore."

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: How nice. You remembered. But of course, that was the day the Germans marched into Paris.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Not an easy day to forget.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I remember every detail. The Germans wore gray, you wore blue.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes. I put that dress away. When the Germans march out, I'll wear it again.  47.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Ricky, you're becoming quite human. I suppose we have to thank you for that, Mademoiselle.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Ilsa, I don't wish to be the one to say it, but it's late.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (glancing at his wristwatch) So it is. And we have a curfew here in Casablanca. It would never do for the Chief of Police to be found drinking after hours and have to fine himself. Rick and Ilsa look at each other. Laszlo signals the waiter

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I hope we didn't overstay our welcome.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: (to Laszlo) Your check, sir. Rick takes the check.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to waiter) Oh, it's my party.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Another precedent gone. This has been a very interesting evening. I'll call you a cab. Gasoline rationing, time of night. Renault leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We'll come again.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Any time.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Say goodnight to Sam for me.  48.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: There's still nobody in the world who can play "As Time Goes By" like Sam.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He hasn't played it in a long time. Ilsa smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Rick and Laszlo nod goodnight to each other. Laszlo and Ilsa start to the door as Rick sits down again and stares off in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilsa and Laszlo leave the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: A very puzzling fellow, this Rick. What sort is he? Ilsa doesn't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh, I really can't say, though I saw him quite often in Paris. They join Renault at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Tomorrow at ten at the Prefect's office.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Goodnight. They get into a waiting cab, leaving Renault on the curb, smoking and looking bemused. The neon sign goes off and the doorway is now illuminated by the revolving beacon from the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers have all gone. The house lights are out. Rick sits alone at a table. There is a glass of bourbon on the table directly in front of him, and another empty glass on the table before an empty chair. Near at hand is a bottle. He fills his glass and drinks it quickly. Rick just sits. His face is entirely expressionless. The beacon light from the airport sweeps around the room creating a mood of unreality. Sam comes in and stands hesitantly beside Rick.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Boss. No answer, as Rick drinks.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Boss!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Boss, ain't you going to bed?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Not right now. Sam now realizes Rick is in a very grim mood.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (lightly)  Ain't you planning on going to bed in the near future?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You ever going to bed?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't sleepy either.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Good. Then have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. Not me, boss.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Then don't have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Boss, let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (emphatically) No, sir. I'm waiting for a lady.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (earnestly) Please, boss, let's go. Ain't nothing but trouble for you here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: She's coming back. I know she's coming back.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: We'll take the car and drive all night. We'll get drunk. We'll go fishing and stay away until she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Shut up and go home, will you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) No, sir. I'm staying right here. Sam sits down at the piano and starts to play softly, 50.  51. improvising.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: They grab Ugarte and she walks in. Well, that's the way it goes. One in, one out. Sam?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, boss?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sam, if it's December 1941 in Casablanca, what time is it in New York?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Uh, my watch stopped.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I bet they're asleep in New York. I'll bet they're asleep all over America. Suddenly he pounds the table and buries his head in his arms. Then he raises his head, trying to regain control. He holds

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine. his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What's that you're playing?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Just a little something of my own.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, stop it. You know what I want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You played it for her and you can play it for me.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I can remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she can stand it, I can. Play it!

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yes, boss. Sam starts to play "As Time Goes By." Rick just stares ahead as orchestra MUSIC slowly joins Sa playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) The Arc de Triomphe from a distance. B) Rick drives a small, open car slowly along the bouleva He puts his arm around Ilsa. The background scenery changes to a country road as she snuggles close to him and puts her head on his shoulder. C) An excursion boat on the Seine. Rick and Ilsa stand at the rail of the boat. They seem to be transported by each other as Ilsa laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilsa fixes flowers at the window while Rick opens champag She walks over and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Who are you really? And what were you before? What did you do and what did you think? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: We said "no questions."

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Here's looking at you, kid. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a swank Paris cafe, Rick and Ilsa dance. They appear to be very much in love as the MUSIC plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilsa flips a coin, then tosses it over to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: A franc for your thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: In America they'd bring only a penny. I guess that's about all they're worth.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I'm willing to be overcharged. Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And I was wondering.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why I'm so lucky. Why I should find you waiting for me to come along.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Why there is no other man in my life?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: That's easy. There was. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for asking. I forgot we said "no questions."

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Well, only one answer can take care of all our questions. They kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF THE GERMAN OCCUPATION OF FR
dialogues.text: A) The rubble of a burned-out, demolished building. A sig with an arrow points to Paris. B) German troops crossing a river.  54. C) Tanks rolling down the road toward Paris. D) German war planes overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man sells newspapers to people crowded around him. Ther is much excitement. Rick and Ilsa sit at a table. They bu a newspaper and begin to read it. Nearby, a group of frightened French people cluster aroun loudspeaker on a wagon. A harsh voice barks out the tragi news of the Nazi push toward Paris.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Nothing can stop them now. Wednesday, Thursday at the latest, they'll be in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (frightened) Richard, they'll find out your record. It won't be safe for you here.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm on their blacklist already, their roll of honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cafe in the Montmartre. A shadow on the floor reflects the cafe sign "La Belle Aurore." Rick, at the bar, gets glasses and a bottle of champagne. He walks over to Ilsa and Sam at the piano. Sam plays "As Time Goes By." Ilsa seems unnerved. There is evidently something on her mind. Rick pours the champagne. His manner is wry, but not the bitter wryness we have seen in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Henri wants us to finish this bottle and then three more. He says he'll water his garden with champagne before he'll let the Germans drink  55. any of it. Sam looks at his glass.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: This sort of takes the sting out of being occupied, doesn't it, Mr. Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You said it! (to Ilsa) Here's looking at you, kid. Suddenly a loudspeaker BLARES out something in German. Ri and Ilsa look at each other, then hurry to the window.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: My German's a little rusty.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It's the Gestapo. They say they expect to be in Paris tomorrow. They are telling us how to act when they come marching in. She smiles faintly.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: With the whole world crumbling, we pick this time to fall in love.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's pretty bad timing. Where were you, say, ten years ago?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Ten years ago? Let's see... (pause as she thinks a bit) ...Yes. I was having a brace put on my teeth. Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Looking for a job. Ilsa looks at him tenderly. Rick takes her in his arms, a kisses her hungrily. While they are locked in an embrace they hear the dull BOOM of cannons.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (frightened) Was that cannon fire, or is it my heart pounding?  56.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (grimly ) Ah, that's the new German 77. And judging by the sound, only about thirty-five miles away. Another BOOM from the cannons.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And getting closer every minute. Here. Drink up. We'll never finish the other three.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The Germans'1ll be here pretty soon now, and they'll come looking for you. And don't forget there's a price on your head. Ilsa reacts to this worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I left a note in my apartment. They'11 know where to find me. Ilsa looks at Rick.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Strange. I know so very little about you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I know very little about you, just the fact that you had your teeth straightened. He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: But be serious, darling. You are in danger and you must leave Paris.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. We must leave.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (seriously) Yes, of course, we --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- The train for Marseilles leaves at five o'clock. I'll pick you up at your hotel at four-thirty.  57.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (quickly) No, no. Not at my hotel. I, uh, I have things to do in the city before I leave. I'll meet you at the station, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All right. At a quarter to five. (a thought strikes him) Say, why don't we get married in Marseilles? Rick chuckles again. Suddenly

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (evasively) That's too far ahead to plan.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess it is a little too far ahead. Well, let's see. What about the engineer? Why can't he marry us on the train?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh, darling! Ilsa turns away and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, why not? The captain ona ship can. It doesn't seem fair that... Hey, hey, what's wrong, kid?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I love you so much, and I hate this war so much. Oh, it's a crazy world. Anything can happen. If you shouldn't get away, I mean, if, if something should keep us apart, wherever they put you and wherever I'll be, I want you to know... She can't go on. She lifts her face to his. He kisses her gently.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Kiss me. Kiss me as if it were the last time. He looks into her eyes, then he does kiss her as though it were going to be the last time.  58. Her hand falls to the table and knocks over a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining very hard at the train station. There is a hectic, fevered excitement, evident in the fac of the people that pass by. This is the last train from P Rick appears in the crowd. He stops and puts his suitcase and glances at his watch. A conductor calls out "All aboard, last train leaving in three minutes." Rain pours over his head and shoulders, but he doesn't se notice. He nervously checks his watch again. Suddenly Sam appears.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Where is she? Have you seen her?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Richard. I can't find her. She checked out of the hotel. But this note came just after you left. Sam pulls an envelope from his pocket. Rick grabs it, ope it, and stares down at the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, I cannot go with you or ever see you again. You must not ask why. Just believe that I love you. Go, my darling, and God bless you. Ilsa Raindrops pour down the letter, smudging the writing.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A whistle BLOwS.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (frantically) That's the last call, Mr. Richard,  59. do you hear me? Come on, Mr. Richard. Let's get out of here. Come on, Mr. Richard, come on. Sam pulls a stunned, reluctant Rick to the train. The tra starts to move just as he boards. From the steps he looks off into the distance, then crumb the letter and tosses it away as the steam from the engin clouds over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up of a glass on the table in the cafe. Rick's hand reaches for it and knocks it over. We now see Rick's face and he's very drunk. Sam walks over to the table to pick up the glass and a fallen chair. Just then the door opens and it's Ilsa. Rick stares at the doorway. Ilsa lingers a moment, then comes over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Rick, I have to talk to you. Her manner is a little uncertain, a little tentative, but with a quiet determination beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh. I saved my first drink to have with you. Here.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No. No, Rick. Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Especially tonight. She sits down in the chair before the empty glass. Her ey are searching his face, but there is no expression on it except a cold and impassive one. Rick reaches for the bottle, and pours himself another dr

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why did you have to come to Casablanca? There are other places.  He takes 60.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have come if I had known that you were here. Believe me, Rick, it's true. I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It's funny about your voice, how it hasn't changed. I can still hear it. "Richard dear, I'll go with you any place. We'll get on a train together and never stop."

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Please don't. Don't, Rick. I can understand how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Huh! You understand how I feel. How long was it we had, honey?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I didn't count the days.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, I did. Every one of them. Mostly I remember the last one. A wow finish. A guy standing ona station platform in the rain with a comical look on his face, because his insides had been kicked out. a drink.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Can I tell you a story, Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Has it got a wow finish?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I don't know the finish yet.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, go on, tell it. Maybe one will come to you as you go along.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It's about a girl who had just come to Paris from her home in Oslo. At the house of some friends she met a man about whom she'd heard her whole life, a very great and courageous man. He opened up for her a whole  61. beautiful world full of knowledge and thoughts and ideals. Everything she knew or ever became was because of him. And she looked up to him and worshipped him with a feeling she supposed was love.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, that's very pretty. I heard a story once. As a matter of fact, I've heard a lot of stories in my time. They went along with the sound of a tinny piano playing in the parlor downstairs, "Mister, I met a man once when I was a kid," it'd always begin. Huh. I guess neither one of our stories was very funny. Tell me, who was it you left me for? Was it Laszlo, or were there others in between? Or aren't you the kind that tells? Ilsa gets up and leaves. Rick's head slumps over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on the door reads: Captain Renault, Prefect de Pol Strasser sits while Renault attends to some paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: I strongly suspect that Ugarte left the letters of transit with Mr. Blaine. I would suggest you search the cafe immediately and thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: If Rick has the letters, he's much too smart to let you find them there.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You give him credit for too much cleverness. My impression was that he's just another blundering American.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: But we mustn't underestimate American blundering. I was with  62. them when they "blundered" into Berlin in 1918. Strasser looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: As to Laszlo, we want him watched twenty-four hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) It may interest you to know that at this very moment he is on his way here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo and Ilsa make their way through the jam in the lob of the Prefecture. Jan and Annina talk to an officer.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (to Jan and Annina) There's nothing we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo and Ilsa enter Renault's office. Renault bows to them both.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I am delighted to see you both. Did you have a good night's rest?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I slept very well.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: That's strange. Nobody is supposed to sleep well in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (coldly) May we proceed with the business?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: With pleasure. Won't you sit down?  63.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you. They take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (now as cold as Laszlo) Very well, Herr Laszlo, we will not mince words. You are an escaped prisoner of the Reich. So far you have been fortunate enough in eluding us. You have reached Casablanca. It is my duty to see that you stay in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Whether or not you succeed is, of course, problematical.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Not at all. Captain Renault's signature is necessary on every exit visa. (turns to Renault) Captain, would you think it is possible that Herr Laszlo will receive a visa?
