dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I am afraid not. My regrets, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps I shall like it in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: And Mademoiselle?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You needn't be concerned about me.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Is that all you wish to tell us?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Don't be in such a hurry. You have all the time in the world. You may be in Casablanca indefinitely... or you may leave for Lisbon tomorrow, on one condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You know the leaders of the underground movement in Paris, in Prague, in Brussels, in Amsterdam, in Oslo, in Belgrade, in Athens.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Even in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Yes, even in Berlin. If you will furnish me with their names and their exact whereabouts, you will have your visa in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: And the honor of having served the Third Reich.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I was in a German concentration camp for a year. That's honor enough for a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You will give us the names?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: If I didn't give them to you ina concentration camp where you had more "persuasive methods" at your disposal, I certainly won't give them to you now. The passionate conviction in his voice now reveals the crusader.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: And what if you track down these men and kill them? What if you murdered all of us? From every corner of Europe, hundreds, thousands, would rise to take our places. Even Nazis can't kill that fast.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Herr Laszlo, you have a reputation for eloquence which I can now understand. But in one respect you are mistaken. You said the enemies of the Reich could all be replaced, but there is one exception. No one  65. could take your place in the event anything unfortunate should occur to you while you were trying to escape.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: You won't dare to interfere with me here. This is still unoccupied France. Any violation of neutrality would reflect on Captain Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Monsieur, insofar as it is in my power --

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: -- Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: By the way, Monsieur, last night you evinced an interest in Signor Ugarte.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I believe you have a message for him?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Nothing important, but may I speak to him now?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You would find the conversation a trifle one-sided. Signor Ugarte is dead. Close-ups of Ilsa, then Laszlo, reveal their disappointme Strasser observes their reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (softly) Oh. Renault holds a report.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I am making out the report now. We haven't quite decided whether he committed suicide or died trying to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you quite finished with us?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: For the time being.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Good day. Renault rings a buzzer and the door is opened for them. As Ilsa and Laszlo leave, an OFFICER comes in.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Undoubtedly their next step will be to the black market.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Captain. Another visa problem has come up.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Show her in.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Renault looks at himself in the mirror and straightens his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black market is a cluttered Arab street of bazaars, shops and stalls. All kinds and races of people mill abou the merchandise which native dealers have on outdoor display. Both men and women are dressed in tropical clothes. The canopies over the stalls give them some protection from t scorching sun. On the surface the atmosphere is merely languid, but underneath lies the sinister workings of illicit trade. A FRENCHMAN and a NATIVE huddle together and talk in low tones.

dialogues.speaker: NATIVE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Monsieur, we would have to handle the police. This is a job for Signor Ferrari.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ferrari?

dialogues.speaker: NATIVE
dialogues.text: It can be most helpful to know Signor Ferrari. He pretty near has a monopoly on the black market here. You will find him over there at the Blue Parrot.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the cafe, a blue parrot sits on a perch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cafe is much less pretentious than Rick's, but well populated. Rick enters and walks through the cafe toward Ferrari's office just as Ferrari emerges with Jan and Annina, who l very disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: There, don't be too downhearted. Perhaps you can come to terms with Captain Renault.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Signor. Jan leads Annina away.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Hello, Ferrari. Signor Ferrari turns around. He's pleased to see Rick.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Ah, good morning, Rick. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I see the bus is in. I'll take my shipment with me.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: He hails 68. No hurry. I'll have it sent over. Have a drink with me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I never drink in the morning. And every time you send my shipment over, it's always just a little bit short.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Carrying charges, my boy, carrying charges. Here, sit down. There's something I want to talk over with you, anyhow. a waiter.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: The bourbon. (to Rick, sighing deeply) The news about Ugarte upset me very much.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're a fat hypocrite. You don't feel any sorrier for Ugarte than I do. He eyes Rick closely.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Of course not. What upsets me is the fact that Ugarte is dead and no one knows where those letters of transit are.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Practically no one.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: If I could lay my hands on those letters, I could make a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So could I. And I'm a poor businessman.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: I have a proposition for whoever has those letters. I will handle the entire transaction, get rid of the letters, take all the risk, for a small percentage.  69.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And the carrying charges?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Naturally there will be a few incidental expenses. That is the proposition I have for whoever has those letters.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (dryly) . I'll tell him when he comes in.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Rick, I'll put my cards on the table. I think you know where those letters are.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, you're in good company. Renault and Strasser probably think so, too. Rick looks out of the window and sees Ilsa at the linen bazaar, then Laszlo walking toward the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That's why I came over here to give them a chance to ransack my place.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Rick, don't be a fool. Take me into your confidence. You need a partner. Rick isn't listening to him. He looks through the open window in the direction of the linen bazaar. Rick gets up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'll be getting back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo reaches the entrance to the cafe as Rick comes out He stops and addresses Rick politely.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signor Ferrari is the fat gent at the table. As he exits, Laszlo looks after him with a puzzled expres

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the linen stall, Ilsa examines a tablecloth which an A vendor is endeavoring to sell. He holds a sign which read "700 francs."

dialogues.speaker: ARAB
dialogues.text: You will not find a treasure like this in all Morocco, Mademoiselle. Only seven hundred francs. Rick walks up behind Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're being cheated. She looks briefly at Rick, then turns away. Her manner is politely formal.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ARAB
dialogues.text: Ah, the lady is a friend of Rick's? For friends of Rick we have a small discount. Did I say seven hundred francs? You can have it for two hundred. Reaching under the counter, he takes out a sign reading " francs", and replaces the other sign with it.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I was in no condition to receive you when you called on me last night.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: ARAB
dialogues.text: Ah, for special friends of Rick's we have a special discount. One hundred francs. He replaces the second sign with a third which reads "100 francs."  71.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Your story had me a little confused. Or maybe it was the bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: ARAB
dialogues.text: I have some tablecloths, some napkins --

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: -- Thank you. I'm really not interested.

dialogues.speaker: ARAB
dialogues.text: Please, one minute. Wait! The Arab hurriedly exits. Ilsa pretends to examine the goods on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why did you come back? To tell me why you ran out on me at the railway station?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, you can tell me now. I'm reasonably sober.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I don't think I will, Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why not? After all, I got stuck with a railway ticket. I think I'm entitled to know.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Last night I saw what has happened to you. The Rick I knew in Paris, I could tell him. He'd understand. But the one who looked at me with such hatred... well, I'll be leaving Casablanca soon and we'll never see each other again. We knew very little about each other when we were in love in Paris. If we leave it that way, maybe we'll remember those days and not Casablanca, not last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you run out on me because you couldn't take it? Because you knew what it would be like, hiding from the police, running away all the time?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You can believe that if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not running away any more. I'm settled now, above a saloon, it's true, but... walk up a flight. I'll be expecting you. Ilsa turns her head away.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All the same, someday you'll lie to Laszlo. You'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No, Rick. No, you see, Victor Laszlo is my husband... and was, even when I knew you in Paris. She walks away into the cafe as Rick stares after her in stunned disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilsa and Laszlo sit with Ferrari.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: I was just telling Monsieur Laszlo that, unfortunately, I am not able to help him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: You see, my dear, the word has gone around.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: (to Ilsa) As leader of all illegal activities in Casablanca, I am an influential and respected man. It would not be worth my life to do anything for Monsieur Laszlo. You, however, are  73. a different matter.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Signor Ferrari thinks it might just be possible to get an exit visa for you.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You mean for me to go on alone?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: And only alone.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I will stay here and keep on trying. I'm sure in a little while --

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: -- We might as well be frank, Monsieur. It will take a miracle to get you out of Casablanca. And the Germans have outlawed miracles.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: We are only interested in two visas, Signor.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Please, Ilsa, don't be hasty.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (firmly) No, Victor, no.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: You two will want to discuss this. Excuse me. I'll be at the bar. Ferrari gets to his feet and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: No, Ilsa, I won't let you stay here. You must get to America. And believe me, somehow I will get out and join you.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: But, Victor, if the situation were different, if I had to stay and there were only a visa for one, would you take it?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (not very convincingly)  74. Yes, I would. Ilsa smiles faintly. She doesn't believe it for evena moment.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes, I see. When I had trouble getting out of Lille, why didn't you leave me there? And when I was sick in Marseilles and held you up for two weeks and you were in danger every minute of the time, why didn't you leave me then?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I meant to, but something always held me up. I love you very much, Ilsa. She smiles again.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Your secret will be safe with me. Ferrari is waiting for our answer. At the bar Ferrari talks to a waiter.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Not more than fifty francs though. Ilsa and Laszlo walk up to him.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We've decided, Signor Ferrari. For the present we'll go on looking for two exit visas. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Well, good luck. But be careful. (a flick of his eyes in the direction of the bazaar) You know you're being shadowed? Laszlo glances in the direction of the bazaar.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Of course. It becomes an instinct. Ferrari looks shrewdly at Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: I observe that you in one respect are  75. a very fortunate man, Monsieur. I am moved to make one more suggestion, why, I do not know, because it cannot possibly profit me, but, have you heard about Signor Ugarte and the letters of transit?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes, something.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Those letters were not found on Ugarte when they arrested him. There's a moments pause as this sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Do you know where they are?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Not for sure, Monsieur, but I will venture to guess that Ugarte left those letters with Monsieur Rick. Ilsa's face darkens. Laszlo quietly observes.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Rick?

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: He is a difficult customer, that Rick. One never knows what he'll do or why. But it is worth a chance.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, thank you for your coffee, Signor. I shall miss that when we leave Casablanca. Ferrari bows.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: It was gracious of you to share it with me. Good day, Mademoiselle, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Good day. As Ilsa and Laszlo leave the cafe, Ferrari nonchalantly swats a fly on a table.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Rick's cafe, the sign is lit up and MUSIC filters out into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, the European has found another TOURIST.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Here's to you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Er, good luck, yes.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: I'd better be going.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Er, my check, please.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: I have to warn you, sir. I beseech you... The European picks his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: This is a dangerous place, full of vultures. Vultures everywhere! Thanks for everything. The tourist laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Er, goodbye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: It has been a pleasure to meet you. He dashes off and collides with Carl.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. As the European hurries away, Carl checks all his pockets to make sure nothing is missing. Sam and Corina play a number, accompanied by the orchestr  Strasser 77. and his crowd enter the cafe and pass Rick's table. Carl brings Rick a bottle and glass.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Monsieur Rick, you are getting to be your best customer. Carl leaves. As Rick lights a cigarette, Renault shows up. He pours

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well, Ricky. I'm very pleased with you. Now you're beginning to live like a Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: That was some going-over your men gave my place this afternoon. We just barely got cleaned up in time to open. a drink for Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well, I told Strasser he wouldn't find the letters here. But I told my men to be especially destructive. You know how that impresses Germans? (taking a sip) Rick, have you got these letters of transit?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Louis, are you pro-Vichy or Free French?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Serves me right for asking a direct question. The subject is closed.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like you're a little late.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Huh? Rick gazes at Yvonne and a GERMAN OFFICER approaching the

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: So Yvonne's gone over to the enemy.  78.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Who knows? In her own way she may constitute an entire second front. I think it's time for me to flatter Major Strasser a little. I'll see you later, Rick. Renault gets up and strolls away. At the bar, Yvonne and the German officer place their orders.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Sacha!

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: French seventy-fives. Yvonne is somewhat drunk already.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Put up a whole row of them, Sacha... starting here and ending here. She indicates with her hand where she wants them.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: We will begin with two. A FRENCH OFFICER at the bar makes a remark to Yvonne.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (in French) Say, you, you are not French to go with a German like this!

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (in French) What are you butting in for?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (in French) I am butting in --

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (breaking in, in French) -- It's none of your business!

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: (in French) No, no, no, no! One minute! (in English) What did you say? Would you kindly  79. repeat it?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: What I said is none of your business!

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: I will make it my business! They begin to fight.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: (in French) Stop! I beg of you! I beg of you, stop! There are exclamations from people nearby. German officer at a nearby table rise, ready to join in. Rick walks up a separates the two men.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to the German) I don't like disturbances in my place. Either lay off politics or get out.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: (in French) Dirty Boche. Someday we'll have our revenge! Renault, Strasser and the other officers sit down again.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You see, Captain, the situation is not as much under control as you believe.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: My dear Major, we are trying to cooperate with your government, but we cannot regulate the feelings of our people. Strasser eyes him closely.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Captain Renault, are you entirely certain which side you're on?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I have no conviction, if that's what you mean. I blow with the wind, and the prevailing wind happens to be from Vichy.  80.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: And if it should change? He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Surely the Reich doesn't admit that possibility? Renault lights a cigarette and puffs away.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: We are concerned about more than Casablanca. We know that every French province in Africa is honey- combed with traitors waiting for their chance, waiting, perhaps, for a leader.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (casually) A leader, like Laszlo?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Uh, huh. I have been thinking. It is too dangerous if we let him go. It may be too dangerous if we let him stay.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I see what you mean. Carl, bottle in hand, approaches the table of a middle-ag German couple, the LEUCHTAGS.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (in German) I brought you the finest brandy. Only the employees drink it here. He pours a drink for each of them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Thank you, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (as he pours) For Mrs. Leuchtag.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Thank you, Carl.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: For Mr. Leuchtag.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Carl, sit down. Have a brandy with us.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: (beaming with happiness) To celebrate our leaving for America tomorrow. Carl sits down.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. I thought you would ask me, so I brought the good brandy and a third glass. He produces a glass from a back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: At last the day has came.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Frau Leuchtag and I are speaking nothing but English now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: So we should feel at home ven ve get to America.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: A very nice idea.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) To America. Mrs. Leuchtag and Carl repeat "To America." They clink glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Liebchen, uh, sweetness heart, what watch? She glances at her wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: Ten watch.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LEUCHTAG
dialogues.text: (surprised) Such much?  82.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Er, you will get along beautifully in America, huh. Annina meets Renault in the hallway as she leaves the gambling room,

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: How's lady luck treating you? Aw, too bad. You'll find him over there. Annina sees Rick and goes to his table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Monsieur Rick?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Could I speak to you for just a moment, please? Rick looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How did you get in here? You're under age.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: I came with Captain Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (cynically) I should have known.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: My husband is with me, too.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He is? Well, Captain Renault's getting broadminded. Sit down. Will you have a drink? Annina shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Do you mind if I do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: No.  83. Rick pours himself a drink

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Monsieur Rick, what kind of man is Captain Renault?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, he's just like any other man, only more so.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: No, I mean, is he trustworthy? Is his word --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Now, just a minute. Who told you to ask me that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: He did. Captain Renault did.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I thought so. Where's your husband?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: At the roulette table, trying to win enough for our exit visa. Well of course, he's losing. Rick looks at her closely.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How long have you been married?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Eight weeks. We come from Bulgaria. Oh, things are very bad there, Monsieur. A devil has the people by the throat. So, Jan and I, we, we do not want our children to grow up in such a country.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (wearily) So you decided to go to America.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Yes, but we have not much money, and travelling is so expensive and difficult. It was much more than we thought to get here. And then Captain Renault sees us and he is so kind. He wants to help us.  There is 84.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: He tells me he can give us an exit visa, but we have no money.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Does he know that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And he is still willing to give you a visa?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Yes, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And you want to know --

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: -- Will he keep his word?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He always has. a silence. Annina is very disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Oh, Monsieur, you are a man. If someone loved you very much, so that your happiness was the only thing that she wanted in the whole world, but she did a bad thing to make certain of it, could you forgive her? Rick stares off into space.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Nobody ever loved me that much.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: And he never knew, and the girl kept this bad thing locked in her heart? That would be all right, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (harshly)  85. You want my advice?

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Go back to Bulgaria.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Oh, but if you knew what it means to us to leave Europe, to get to America! Oh, but if Jan should find out! He is such a boy. In many ways I am so much older than he is.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, well, everybody in Casablanca has problems. Yours may work out. You'll excuse me. Rick abruptly rises.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: (tonelessly) Thank you, Monsieur. He quickly goes off, leaving Annina alone at the table. She remains seated, too demoralized to move. While Rick checks the reservation list, Ilsa and Laszlo e the cafe. In the background we hear Sam playing, ironically enough, "It Had to Be You." Rick greets Ilsa and Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Good evening. You see, here we are again.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I take that as a great compliment to Sam. (to Ilsa) I suppose he means to you Paris of, well, happier days. Laszlo looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) He does. Could we have a table close to him?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: And as far away from Major Strasser as possible.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, the geography may be a little difficult to arrange. Rick snaps his fingers for the headwaiter.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Paul! Table thirty!

dialogues.speaker: HEADWAITER
dialogues.text: (to Ilsa and Laszlo) Yes, sir. Right this way, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Ilsa) I'll have Sam play "As Time Goes By." I believe that's your favorite tune.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thank you. Rick walks over to Sam and whispers something to him. Sam stops what he is playing and begins "As Time Goes By." He shakes his head as Rick leaves. A waiter appears at Ilsa and Laszlo's table.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Two cognacs, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jan sits at the roulette table. He has only three chips left and seems bewildered. As Rick comes up the croupier speaks to Jan.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Do you wish to place another bet, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No, no, I guess not.  87. Rick stands behind Jan.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Jan) Have you tried twenty-two tonight? I said, twenty-two. Jan looks at Rick, then at the chips in his hand. He paues, then puts the chips on twenty-two. Rick and the croupier exchange looks. The croupier understands what Rick wants him to do. He spins the wheel Carl follows the proceedings, fascinated. The wheel stops spinning.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: (in French) Twenty-two, black, twenty-two. A winner. Renault, at a nearby table, takes notice of wha is happening. The croupier pushes a pile of chips onto twenty-two and J reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (not even looking at Jan) Leave it there. Jan hesitates, then withdraws his hands. Carl continues to watch. The wheel spins. Nobody speaks while it spins. It stops.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Twenty-two, black. Another winner. The croupier shoves a pile of chips towar Jan.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (to Jan) Cash it in and don't come back. Jan rises to go to the cashier. A CUSTOMER complains to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, are you sure this place is honest?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (fervently) Honest! As honest as the day is long! Meanwhile, Rick has walked over to the croupier.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How we doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Well, a couple of thousand less than I thought there would be. Rick smiles slightly and goes toward the door. Annina runs up to him and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Monsieur Rick, I --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- He's just a lucky guy.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (solicitously) Monsieur Rick, may I get you a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No thanks, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Monsieur Rick! Renault, seeing that Jan has won, gets up from his table follow Rick. Jan and Annina stop him on the way.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Captain Renault, may I --

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: -- Oh, not here, please. Come to my office in the morning. We'll do everything business-like.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We'll be there at six.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I'll be there at ten. I am very happy for both of you. Still, it's very strange that you won.  89. He looks over and sees Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not so strange. I'll see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: ANNINA
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Captain Renault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, Carl whispers in Sacha's ear. Sacha says "No! and runs to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: SACHA
dialogues.text: Boss, you've done a beautiful thing. He kisses Rick on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Go away, you crazy Russian! Carl pours a brandy for Rick. Pretending not to do so, Rick glances in Ilsa's direction Renault comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: As I suspected, you're a rank sentimentalist.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Why?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (chidingly) Why do you interfere with my little romances?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Put it down as a gesture to love.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly) Well, I forgive you this time. But I'll be in tomorrow night with a breathtaking blonde, and it will make me very happy if she loses. Uh huh! He smiles and walks away. Laszlo comes up to Rick.  90.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Monsieur Blaine, I wonder if I could talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Well, isn't there some other place? It's rather confidential, what I have to say.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: My office.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Laszlo sit and discuss Laszlo's dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: You must know it's very important I get out of Casablanca. It's my privilege to be one of the leaders of a great movement. You know what I have been doing. You know what it means to the work, to the lives of thousands and thousands of people that I be free to reach America and continue my work.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in politics. The problems of the world are not in my department. I'm a saloon keeper.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: My friends in the underground tell me that you have quite a record. You ran guns to Ethiopia. You fought against the fascists in Spain.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What of it?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Isn't it strange that you always  91. happened to be fighting on the side of the underdog?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes. I found that a very expensive hobby, too. But then I never was much of a businessman. Rick gets up, as does Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Are you enough of a businessman to appreciate an offer of a hundred thousand francs?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I appreciate it, but I don't accept it.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I'll raise it to two hundred thousand.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: My friend, you could make it a million francs, or three, my answer would still be the same.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: There must be some reason why you won't let me have them.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: There is. I suggest that you ask your wife.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I said, ask your wife.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: My wife? Laszlo looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes. Rick and Laszlo hear MALE VOICES singing downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of German officers stand around the piano singing the "Wacht am Rhein."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick stands at the balcony outside his office and watches the Germans below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, Renault watches with raised eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo's lips are very tight as he listens to the song. He starts down the step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo passes the table where Ilsa sits and goes straight to the orchestra. Yvonne, sitting at a table with her German officer, stare down into her drink. Laszlo speaks to the orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Play the Marseillaise! Play it! Members of the orchestra glance toward the steps, toward who nods to them. Laszlo and Corina sing as they start to play. Strasser conducts the German singing in an attempt to drown out th competition. People in the cafe begin to sing the "Marseillaise." After a while, Strasser and his officers give up and sit down. The "Marseillaise" continues, however. Yvonne jumps up and sings with tears in her eyes. Ilsa, overcome with emotion, looks proudly at Laszlo, who sings with passion.  93. Finally the whole cafe stands, singing, their faces aglow. The song finishes on a high, triumphant note. Yvonne's face is exalted. She deliberately faces the alco where the Germans are watching. She SHOUTS at the top of her lungs.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: Vive La France! Vive la democracie!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Vive La France! Vive la democracie! People clap and cheer. Strasser is very angry. He strides across the floor towar Renault who is standing at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: You see what I mean? If Laszlo's presence in a cafe can inspire this unfortunate demonstration, what more will his presence in Casablanca bring on? I advise that this place be shut up at once.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (innocently) But everybody's having such a good time.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Yes, much too good a time. The place is to be closed.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: But I have no excuse to close it.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (snapping) Find one. Several French officers surround Laszlo, offering him a d Renault thinks a moment, then blows a loud BLAST on his whistle. The room grows quiet, all eyes turn toward Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (loudly) Everybody is to leave here immediately! This cafe is closed until further notice!  An angry murmur starts among the crowd. begin to leave. Clear the room at once! Rick comes quickly up to Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How can you close me up? On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I am shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on in here! This display of nerve leaves Rick at a loss. comes out of the gambling room and up to Renault. He hand him a roll of bills.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Your winnings, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you very much. He turns to the crowd again.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Everybody out at once! As the cafe empties, Strasser approaches Ilsa. is abrupt but cordial.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle, after this disturbance it is not safe for Laszlo to stay in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: This morning you implied it was not safe for him to leave Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: That is also true, except for one destination, to return to occupied France.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Occupied France?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Under a safe conduct from me.
People get up and The croupier His manner  95. (with intensity) What value is that? You may recall what German guarantees have been worth in the past.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: There are only two other alternatives for him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: It is possible the French authorities will find a reason to put him in the concentration camp here.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: And the other alternative?

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: My dear Mademoiselle, perhaps you have already observed that in Casablanca, human life is cheap. Good night, Mademoiselle. She looks at him, understanding what he means. He bows and exits as Laszlo arrives at the table. They start out of the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: What happened with Rick?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We'll discuss it later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilsa and Laszlo walk to their room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo switches on the light as they enter. While Ilsa takes off some jewelry he walks to the window and peers out into the darkeness. Below and across the street, a man stands under an arch. Laszlo watches him, then draws down the shade.  96.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Our faithful friend is still there.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Victor, please, don't go to the underground meeting tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (soberly) I must. Besides, it isn't often that a man has a chance to display heroics before his wife. He crosses to a table, takes a cigarette from a box, and strikes a match.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Don't joke. After Major Strasser's warning tonight, I am frightened.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I am frightened too. Shall I remain here in our hotel room hiding, or shall I carry on the best I can? He lights the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Whatever I'd say, you'd carry on. Victor, why don't you tell me about Rick? What did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Apparently he has the letters.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: But no intention of selling them. One would think if sentiment wouldn't persuade him, money would. Ilsa is now noticeably uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Did he give any reason?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: He suggested I ask you.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Ask me?  97.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes. He said, "Ask your wife." I don't know why he said that. Laszlo turns off the light. Ilsa walks over to the couch sits down.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Well, our friend outside will think we've retired by now. I'll be going in a few minutes. He sits down on the couch next to her. A silence falls between them. It grows strained. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Ilsa, I --

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: -- Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: When I was in the concentration camp, were you lonely in Paris? Ilsa still cannot look at him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes, Victor, I was.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) I know how it is to be lonely. (very quietly) Is there anything you wish to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (speaking low) No, Victor, there isn't.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I love you very much, my dear. Ilsa finally turns to look at Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes, Yes I know. Victor, whatever I do, will you believe that I, that --

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: -- You don't even have to say it. I'll believe. Goodnight, dear.  98. He bends down and kisses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Goodnight. She watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Victor! She gets up and follows him to the door. He opens it. In the slit of light from the hall we see Ilsa's face, now strained and worried. She hesitates for a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Of course, I'll be careful. He kisses her on the cheek and goes out the door. She sta there for a few seconds, then crosses to look out of the window. The figure in the archway is gone. She sees Victor walkin down the street and closes the blind again. Ilsa gets a cloak from the bedroom, and leaves the hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Carl sit by the bar and look over ledgers. Carl is busy figuring. He looks up at Rick.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Well, you are in pretty good shape, Herr Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How long can I afford to stay closed?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Oh, two weeks, maybe three.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe I won't have to. A bribe has worked before. In the meantime, everybody stays on salary.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Herr Rick. Sacha will be happy to hear it. I owe him money.  99. Carl laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Now you finish locking up, will you, Carl?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I will. Then I am going to the meeting of the --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) -- Don't tell me where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Monsieur Rick. Rick walks up the stairs to his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick opens the door and goes inside the dark room. Light from the hall reveals a figure by the window. He lights a small lamp. Ilsa faces him, her face white but determined Rick pauses for a moment in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: How did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: The stairs from the street. Ilsa comes over to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I told you this morning you'd come around, but this is a little ahead of schedule. Well, won't you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Richard, I had to see you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You use "Richard" again? We're back  He walks 100. in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Your unexpected visit isn't connected by any chance with the letters of transit? It seems that as long as I have those letters I'll never be lonely.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You can ask any price you want, but you must give me those letters.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I went through all that with your husband. It's no deal.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I know how you feel about me, but I'm asking you to put your feelings aside for something more important.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Do I have to hear again what a great man your husband is? What an important cause he's fighting for?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It was your cause, too. In your own way, you were fighting for the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm not fighting for anything anymore, except myself. I'm the only cause I'm interested in. over to the window and Ilsa follows.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Richard, Richard, we loved each other once. If those days meant anything at all to you --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (interrupting, harshly) -- I wouldn't bring up Paris if I were you. It's poor salesmanship.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Please. Please listen to me. If you knew what really happened, if  101. you only knew the truth --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (cutting in) -- I wouldn't believe you, no matter what you told me. You'd say anything now to get what you want. Rick walks over to a table and opens a cigarette box, but finds it empty.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You want to feel sorry for yourself, don't you? With so much at stake, all you can think of is your own feelings. One woman has hurt you, and you take revenge on the rest of the world. You're a, you're a coward, and a weakling. There are tears in her eyes now. He turns He stops her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No. Oh, Richard, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, but, but you, you are our last hope. If you don't help us, Victor Laszlo will die in Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What of it? I'm going to die in Casablanca. It's a good spot for it. away to light a cigarette, then back to Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Now if you -- short as he sees Ilsa holding a small revolver in It's pointed directly at him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: -- All right. I tried to reason with you. I tried everything. Now I want those letters. Get them for me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I don't have to. I've got them right here.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Put them on the table.  102.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: For the last time, put them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: If Laszlo and the cause mean so much to you, you won't stop at anything. All right, I'll make it easier for you. He moves closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Go ahead and shoot. You'll be doing me a favor. Her hand drops down, and there are tears in her eyes agai She turns and walks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Richard, I tried to stay away. I thought I would never see you again, that you were out of my life. Rick follows her and takes her in his arms. He presses he tight to him.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: The day you left, if you knew what I went through! If you knew how much I loved you, how much I still love you! Rick kisses her passionately. She is lost in his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his window, Rick watches the revolving beacon light the airport. Ilsa sits on the couch. On a table before her rests a bot of champagne along with two half-filled glasses. Rick walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: It wasn't long after we were married that Victor went back to Czechoslovakia. They needed him in Prague, but there the Gestapo were waiting for him. Just a two-line item in the paper: "Victor Laszlo apprehended. Sent to concen- tration camp." I was frantic. For months I tried to get word. Then it came. He was dead, shot trying to escape. I was lonely. I had nothing. Not even hope. Then I met you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Why weren't you honest with me? Why did you keep your marriage a secret? Rick sits down with Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn't my secret, Richard. Victor wanted it that way. Not even our closest friends knew about our marriage. That was his way of protecting me. I knew so much about his work, and if the Gestapo found out I was his wife it would be dangerous for me and for those working with me.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: When did you first find out he was alive?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Just before you and I were to leave Paris together. A friend came and told me that Victor was alive. They were hiding him in a freight car on the outskirts of Paris. He was sick, he needed me. I wanted to tell you, but I, I didn't care. I knew, I knew you wouldn't have left Paris, and the Gestapo would have caught you. Sol... well, well, you know the rest.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Huh. But it's still a story without an ending. What about now?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Now? I don't know. I know that  104. I'll never have the strength to leave you again.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And Laszlo?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh, you'll help him now, Richard, won't you? You'll see that he gets out? Then he'll have his work, all that he's been living for.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All except one. He won't have you. Ilsa puts her head on Rick's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I can't fight it anymore. I ran away from you once. I can't do it again. Oh, I don't know what's right any longer. You'll have to think for both of us, for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All right, I will. Here's looking at you, kid.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: I wish I didn't love you so much. She snuggles closer to Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo and Carl make their way through the darkness towar a side entance of Rick's. They run inside the entryway. The headlights of a speeding police car sweep toward them They flatten themselves against a wall to avoid detection The lights move past them.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I think we lost them.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm afraid they caught some of the others.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Come inside. Come.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo and Carl enter and cross toward the bar, out of breath from their exertion.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Come inside. I will help you. Come in here.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you. Carl goes behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I will give you some water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick and Ilsa hear voices below. Rick crosses to the door He opens it just enough to see below, and turns off the l Ilsa stands just in back of him. She makes a move as if to go out to the balcony but Rick's pushes her back. She withdraws behind the door. Rick walks out to the balcony railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick sees Carl attending to Laszlo, who appears to be inj

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Carl, what happened? Both Carl and Laszlo look up.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (excitedly) The police break up our meeting. Herr Rick! We escaped in the last moment.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Come up here a minute. Carl looks up wonderingly, then starts toward the stairwa  106.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, I come.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I want you to turn out the light in the rear entrance. It might attract the police.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: But Sacha always puts out that light --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Tonight he forgot.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, I come, I will do it. Carl climbs the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl enters Rick's apartment and sees Ilsa. He looks at Rick and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I want you to take Miss Lund home.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick comes down the stairs. Laszlo wraps one of the small bar towels around his cut wrist. Rick looks questioningly the injured hand.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: It's nothing. Just a little cut. We had to get through a window. Rick walks to the bar, picks up a bottle, and pours a dri

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, this might come in handy.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thank you.  107.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Had a close one, eh?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes, rather. Laszlo takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Don't you sometimes wonder if it's worth all this? I mean what you're fighting for?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: We might as well question why we breathe. If we stop breathing, we'll die. If we stop fighting our enemies, the world will die.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: What of it? Then it'll be out of it's misery. Rick reaches in his jacket for his cigarette case, opens and takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: You know how you sound, Monsieur Blaine? Like a man who's trying to convince himself of something he doesn't believe in his heart. Each of us has a destiny, for good or for evil.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, I get the point. Rick lights his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I wonder if you do. I wonder if you know that you're trying to escape from yourself and that you'll never succeed.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You seem to know all about my destiny.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I know a good deal more about you than you suspect. I know, for instance, that you are in love with a woman. It is perhaps strange that we both should be in love with the  He looks Suddenly 108. same woman. The first evening I came here in this cafe, I knew there was something between you and Ilsa. Since no one is to blame, I, I demand no explanation. I ask only one thing. You won't give me the letters of transit. All right. But I want my wife to be safe. I ask you as a favor to use the letters to take her away from Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You love her that much?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Apparently you think of me only as the leader of a cause. Well, I am also a human being. away for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes, I love her that much. there is a CRASH at the door of the cafe, followed by the forced entry of several gendarmes. A French office walks in and addresses Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Mr. Laszlo?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: You will come with us. We have a warrant for your arrest.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: On what charge?

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
dialogues.text: Captain Renault will discuss that with you later.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It seems that destiny has taken a hand. Laszlo looks for a moment at Rick, then in dignified sile crosses to the officer. Together they walk toward the doo Rick's eyes follow them, but his expression reveals nothi of his feelings.  109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renault fingers Renault and the sits at his desk and smokes while Rick nervously his hat. They're interrupted by an orderly. hands some forms to the orderly, who then exits, conversation continues.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: But you haven't any actual proof, and you know it. This isn't Germany or occupied France. All you can do is fine him a few thousand francs and give him thirty days. You might as well let him go now.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Ricky, I'd advise you not to be too interested in what happens to Laszlo. If by any chance you were to help him escape --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- What makes you think I'd stick my neck out for Laszlo?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Because one, you've bet ten thousand francs he'd escape. Two, you have the letters of transit, now don't bother to deny it. And, well, you might do it simply because you don't like Strasser's looks. As a matter of fact, I don't like him either.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, they're all excellent reasons.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Don't count too much on my friendship, Ricky. In this matter I'm powerless. Besides, I might lose ten thousand francs.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're not very subtle, but you are effective. I, I get the point. Yes, I have the letters, but I intend using them myself. I'm leaving Casablanca on tonight's plane, the last plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And I'm taking a friend with me. One you'll appreciate.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: What friend?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Ilsa Lund. (pause) That ought to put your mind to rest about my helping Laszlo escape. The last man I want to see in America.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You didn't come here to tell me this. You have the letters of transit. You can fill in your name and hers and leave any time you please. Why are you interested in what happens to Laszlo? Renault gets out of his chair and crosses to the front of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm not. But I am interested in what happens to Ilsa and me. We have a legal right to go, that's true. But people have been held in Casablanca in spite of their legal rights. Renault retrieves a fresh cigarette from a box on his des

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: What makes you think we want to hold you? Renault chain-lights his new cigarette with the old one.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Ilsa is Laszlo's wife. She probably knows things that Strasser would like to know. Louis, I'll make a deal with you. Instead of this petty charge you have against him, you can get something really big, something that would chuck him in a concentration camp for years. That would be quite a feather in your cap, wouldn't it?  141.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: It certainly would. Germany... Vichy would be very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Then release him. You be at my place a half hour before the plane leaves. Renault sits back down in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'll arrange to have Laszlo come there to pick up the letters of transit, and that'll give you the criminal grounds on which to make the arrest. You get him, and we get away. To the Germans that last will be just a minor annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (puzzled) There's still something about this business I don't quite understand. Miss Lund, she's very beautiful, yes, but you were never interested in any woman.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, she isn't just any woman. Rick stares at the floor, then looks back up at Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I see. How do I know you'll keep your end of the bargain?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'll make the arrangements right now with Laszlo in the visitor's pen.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Ricky, I'm going to miss you. Apparently you're the only one in Casablanca who has even less scruples than I.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Ricky.  112. Renault presses a button on his desk, triggering a BUZZER The door to Renault's office opens. Rick rises to go.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And by the way, call off your watchdogs when you let him go. I don't want them around this afternoon. I'm taking no chances, Louis, not even with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter brings tea to Rick and Ferrari, who sit alone at table in a secluded nook off the main room.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Shall we draw up the papers, or is our handshake good enough?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It's certainly not good enough. But since I'm in a hurry, it'll have to do. Ferrari pours a cup for Rick, who takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Ah, to get out of Casablanca and go to America! You're a lucky man.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, my agreement with Sam's always been that he gets twenty-five percent of the profits. That still goes.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I happen to know that he gets ten percent. But he's worth twenty- five.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And Abdul and Carl and Sacha, they stay with the place, or I don't sell.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: Of course they stay. Rick's wouldn't be Rick's without them.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Well, so long. Rick gets up, followed by Ferrari. They shake hands to se  113. the deal. He walks to the door, then stops and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Don't forget, you owe Rick's a hundred cartons of American cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI
dialogues.text: I shall remember to pay it... to myself. Rick leaves. Ferrari picks up a fly swatter from the tabl and swats at a fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls quickly to a stop just outside the cafe. On the door a huge placard reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Order of the Prefect of Police

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick sits at a table inside and reads the letters of tran He hears a KNOCK on the door and puts them away in his po He opens the door and Renault walks in.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I was informed just as Laszlo was about to leave the hotel, so I knew I'd be on time.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I thought I asked you to tie up your watchdogs.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, he won't be followed here. Renault looks around the empty cafe.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You know, this place will never be  114. the same without you, Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Yes, I know what you mean, but I've already spoken to Ferrari. You'll still win at roulette.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Is everything ready? Rick points at his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I have the letters right here.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Tell me, when we searched the place, where were they?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Sam's piano.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Serves me right for not being musical. They hear the CRUNCH of tires as a car pull up.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh. Here they are. You'd better wait in my office. Renault walks up the stairs to Rick's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo pays the cab driver. Ilsa quickly walks toward the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (to driver) Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick opens the door. Ilsa rushes in. Her intensity reveal the strain she is under. Rick grabs her by both arms and pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Richard, Victor thinks I'm leaving  115. with him. Haven't you told him?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: But it's all right, isn't it? You were able to arrange everything?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Everything is quite all right.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Oh, Rick! She looks at him with a vaguely questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: We'll tell him at the airport. The less time to think, the easier for all of us. Please trust me. Ilsa pauses and looks at Rick, unsure for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes, I will. Laszlo comes in and closes the door behind himself.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Monsieur Blaine, I don't know how to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Oh, save it. We've still lots of things to do. They all walk towards the bar. Laszlo deposits his hat on a nearby table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renault opens the office door and peers down at the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: I brought the money, Monsieur Blaine.  116.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Keep it. You'll need it in America.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: But we made a deal.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (cutting him short) Oh, never mind about that. You won't have any trouble in Lisbon, will you?

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: No. It's all arranged.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Good. I've got the letters right here, all made out in blank. He takes out the letters.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All you have to do is fill in the signatures. He hands them to Laszlo, who takes them gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo! All three hear footsteps and turn to see Renault walking towards them from the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo, you are under arrest... (as he walks toward them) on a charge of accessory to the murder of the couriers from whom these letters were stolen. Ilsa and Laszlo are both caught completely off guard. The turn towards Rick, bewildered. Horror is in Ilsa's eyes. Renault takes the letters.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Oh, you are surprised about my friend Ricky? Obviously the situation delights Renault. He smiles as he turns toward Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: The explanation is quite simple.  117. Love, it seems, has triumphed over virtue. Thank -- Suddenly the smile fades. In Rick's hand is a gun, which he levels at Renault.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Not so fast, Louis. Nobody's going to be arrested. Not for a while yet.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Have you taken leave of your senses?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I have. Sit down over there.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Put that gun down. Renault then walks toward Rick. Rick puts out his arm to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Louis, I wouldn't like to shoot you, but I will, if you take one more step. Renault halts for a moment and studies Rick.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances, I will sit down. He walks to a table and sits.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (sharply) Keep your hands on the table. He takes out a cigarette case.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I suppose you know what you're doing, but I wonder if you realize what this means?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I do. We've got plenty of time to discuss that later.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Call off your watch-dogs you said.  118.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Just the same, you call the airport and let me hear you tell them. And remember, this gun's pointed right at your heart.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: That is my least vulnerable spot. As Renault picks up the phone and dials, Rick takes back the letters.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, is this the airport? This is Captain Renault speaking. There'll be two letters of transit for the Lisbon plane. There's to be no trouble about them. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strasser is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? He hangs up the receiver and presses a BUZZER on his desk An officer quickly enters.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (to officer) My car, quickly!

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (saluting) Zu Befehl, Herr Major. The officer exits and Strasser resumes on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: This is Major Strasser. Have a squad of police meet me at the airport at once. At once! Do you hear? He hangs up the receiver and, grabbing for his cap, hurriedly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire airport is surrounded by a heavy fog. The outl of the transport plane is barely visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uniformed ORDERLY uses a telephone near the hangar door On the airfield a transport plane is being readied.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Hello. Hello, radio tower? Lisbon plane taking off in ten minutes. East runway. Visibility: one and one half miles. Light ground fog. Depth of fog: approximately 500. Ceiling: unlimited. Thank you. He hangs up and moves to a car that has just pulled up outside the hangar. Renault gets out while the orderly stands at attention. He's closely followed by Rick, right hand in the pocket of his trench coat, covering Renault with a gun. Laszlo and Ilsa emerge from the rear of the car.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (indicating the orderly) Louis, have your man go with Mr. Laszlo and take care of his luggage.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: (bowing ironically) Certainly Rick, anything you say. (to orderly) Find Mr. Laszlo's luggage and put it it on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. This way please. The orderly escorts Laszlo off in the direction of the pl Rick takes the letters of transit out of his pocket and hands them to Renault, who turns and walks toward the han

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: If you don't mind, you fill in the names. That will make it even more official.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: You think of everything, don't you?  120.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (quietly) And the names are Mr. and Mrs. Victor Laszlo. Renault stops dead in his tracks, and turns around. Both Ilsa and Renault look at Rick with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: But why my name, Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Because you're getting on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (confused) I don't understand. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm staying here with him 'til the plane gets safely away. Rick's intention suddenly dawns on Ilsa.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No, Richard, no. What has happened to you? Last night we said --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- Last night we said a great many things. You said I was to do the thinking for both of us. Well, I've done a lot of it since then and it all adds up to one thing. You're getting on that plane with Victor where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (protesting) But Richard, no, I, I --

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: -- You've got to listen to me. Do you have any idea what you'd have to look forward to if you stayed here? Nine chances out of ten we'd both wind up in a concentration camp. Isn't that true, Louis? Renault countersigns the papers.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Major Strasser would  121. insist.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: You're saying this only to make me go.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm saying it because it's true. Inside of us we both know you belong with Victor. You're part of his work, the thing that keeps him going. If that plane leaves the ground and you're not with him, you'll regret it.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: But what about us?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we'd lost it, until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night.

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: And I said I would never leave you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going you can't follow. what I've got to do you can't be any part of. Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now... Ilsa's eyes well up with tears. Rick puts his hand to her chin and raises her face to meet his own.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Here's looking at you, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Strasser drives at break-neck speed towards the air He HONKS his horn furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laszlo returns. Rick walks into the hangar and Renault hands him the letters. He walks back out to Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Everything in order?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: All except one thing. There's something you should know before you leave.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: (sensing what is coming) Monsieur Blaine, I don't ask you to explain anything.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm going to anyway, because it may make a difference to you later on. You said you knew about Ilsa and me.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: But you didn't know she was at my place last night when you were. She came there for the letters of transit. Isn't that true, Ilsa?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: (facing Laszlo) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (forcefully) She tried everything to get them, and nothing worked. She did her best to convince me that she was still in love with me, but that was all over long ago. For your sake, she pretended it wasn't, and I let her pretend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Here it is. Rick hands the letters to Laszlo.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Thanks. I appreciate it. Laszlo extends his hand to Rick, who grasps it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: And welcome back to the fight. This time I know our side will win. On the airfield the airplane engine TURNS OVER and the propellers start turning. They all turn to see the plane readying for take-off. Ilsa looks at Rick and he returns her stare with a blank expression. He then glances at Laszlo, as does Ilsa. Then Laszlo breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: LASZLO
dialogues.text: Are you ready Ilsa?

dialogues.speaker: ILSA
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm ready. (to Rick) Goodbye, Rick. God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You better hurry, or you'll miss that plane. Rick watches as Ilsa and Laszlo walk very deliberately towards the plane.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Well I was right. You area sentimentalist.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Stay where you are. I don't know what you're talking about. Rick puts a cigarette in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: What you just did for Laszlo, and that fairy tale that you invented to send Ilsa away with him. I knowa  124. little about women, my friend. She went, but she knew you were lying.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Anyway, thanks for helping me out.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I suppose you know this isn't going to be pleasant for either of us, especially for you. I'll have to arrest you of course.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: As soon as the plane goes, Louis. The door to the plane is closed by an attendant and it slowly taxies down the field. Suddenly a speeding car comes to a stop outside the hanga Strasser alights from the car and runs toward Renault.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: What is the meaning of that phone call?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Victor Laszlo is on that plane. Renault nods toward the field. Strasser turns to see the plane taxiing towards the runway.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Why do you stand here? Why don't you stop him?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Ask Monsieur Rick. Strasser looks briefly at Rick, then makes a step towards the telephone just inside the hangar door.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Get away from that phone. Strasser stops in his tracks, looks at Rick, and sees tha he is armed.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: (steely) I would advise you not to interfere.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I was willing to shoot Captain Renault, and I'm willing to shoot  125. you. Strasser watches the plane in agony. His eyes dart toward the telephone. He runs toward it and desperately grabs th receiver.

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Put that phone down!

dialogues.speaker: STRASSER
dialogues.text: Get me the Radio Tower!

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Put it down! Strasser, one hand holding the receiver, pulls out a pist with the other hand, and SHOOTS quickly at Rick. The bull misses its mark. Rick now SHOOTS at Strasser, who crumples to the ground. At the sound of an approaching car both men turn. A polic car SPEEDS in and comes to a stop near Renault. Four gendarmes hurriedly jump out. In the distance the plane turns onto the runway. The gendarmes run to Renault. The first one hurriedly salutes him.

dialogues.speaker: GENDARME
dialogues.text: Mon Capitaine!

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Major Strasser's been shot. Renault pauses and looks at Rick. Rick returns Renault's gaze with expressionless eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Round up the usual suspects.

dialogues.speaker: GENDARME
dialogues.text: Oui, mon Capitaine. The gendarmes take Strasser's body away and then drive of Renault walks inside the hangar, picks up a bottle of Vic water, and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Rick, you're not only a sentimentalist, but you've become a patriot.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Maybe, but it seemed like a good time to start.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: I think perhaps you're right. As he pours the water into a glass, Renault sees the Vich label and quickly DROPS the bottle into a trash basket wh he then KICKS over. He walks over and stands beside Rick. They both watch the plane take off, maintaining their gaze until it disappear into the clouds. Rick and Louis slowly walk away from the hangar toward th runway.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: It might be a good idea for you to disappear from Casablanca for a while. There's a Free French garrison over at Brazzaville. I could be induced to arrange a passage.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: My letter of transit? I could use a trip. But it doesn't make any difference about our bet. You still owe me ten thousand francs.

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: And that ten thousand francs should pay our expenses.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Our expenses?

dialogues.speaker: RENAULT
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Louis, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship. The two walk off together into the night. FADE OUT.
